title: Trump to Launch Fresh Immigration Overhaul Bid
summary: Plan aims to curb refugees and family members, and boost skill-based visas. WASHINGTON-President Trump will make a fresh bid Thursday to remake U.S. immigration policy, proposing an expansion of skills-based visas offset by new restrictions on family members' immigration-a proposal likely to ignite a dispute over issues that divide political parties and the country.

title: Regulator Vows Scrutiny of Next Wells Fargo Chief Executive
summary: Comptroller of the Currency says he remains disappointed with the bank and that his office will vet its next CEO. WASHINGTON-A top banking regulator told lawmakers Wednesday his agency plans to keep close tabs on Wells Fargo & Co. and will vet the next chief executive at the lender.

title: Who Pays the Trump Tariffs? We Do, These Americans Say
summary: Customers of one inflatable-boat company bear most of its tariffs-which turns out to be typical. Port Jefferson, N.Y.

title: California Governor Pushes to Limit PG&E's Bankruptcy Extension
summary: Gov. Gavin Newsom said state's largest utility doesn't deserve to keep a tight grip on bankruptcy case for six more months. California Gov. Gavin Newsom is asking a bankruptcy judge to keep PG&E Corp. on a short leash, requesting a cap on how long the state's largest utility has to steer a course out of bankruptcy without worrying about rival restructuring proposals.

title: Cisco's Revenue Rises as Investors Weigh Possible Tariff Effects
summary: 'We see very minimal impact at this point,' CEO says of higher tariffs in the U.S.-China trade dispute. Cisco Systems Inc.'s results for the most recent quarter beat Wall Street targets, and the networking giant said it sees little effect from higher tariffs in a U.S.-China trade clash.

title: 'Did You Bring Your Handcuffs?'
summary: At least Bill Barr has a sense of humor about the partisan furies.. At least Bill Barr hasn't lost his sense of humor. At a ceremony Wednesday on Capitol Hill, the Attorney General jokingly asked Speaker Nancy Pelosi, as quoted by two congressional reporters: "Madam Speaker, did you bring your handcuffs?"

title: Washington's Disaster Cynicism
summary: Puerto Rico is already getting $40 billion in relief.. Few spectacles in Washington are as cynical as disaster relief, but the current debate is even worse than usual. Democrats are portraying Puerto Rico as a victim of Republican bigotry, though the island has received billions since Hurricane Maria in 2017.

title: Democratic Presidential Hopeful Yang's Speeches Drove Earnings
summary: Proponent of universal basic income discloses income of $150,000 last year. WASHINGTON-Democratic presidential candidate Andrew Yang, a self-described tech entrepreneur and philanthropist, earned about $150,000 last year, according to his newly released personal financial disclosure form.

title: Macy's Posts Rise in Same-Store Sales; Full-Year Outlook Outlook
summary: Retailer says more customers are making purchases through digital channels. Macy's Inc. posted stronger-than-expected growth in a key sales metric in the latest quarter as the retailer said it benefited from more customers making purchases through digital channels.

title: Dude, Where's Your Brain?
summary: Be safe, I told my teen nephew. I should have been more specific.. I took the chance to let my 16-year-old nephew in on the widely held medical opinion that the prefrontal cortex-the part of the brain involved in making decisions and controlling impulses-isn't fully developed until age 25.

title: Back to the Impeachment Future
summary: The expiration in 1999 of the independent counsel law was supposed to avoid situations like this.. It's happening again. The Mueller report is leading to cries for impeachment. By virtue of special counsel Robert Mueller's pivotal judgment to produce a lavishly detailed report plainly designed to find its way into the public domain, we have been transported back to the era of the independent-counsel law, which was allowed to expire in 1999 in the immediate wake of the impeachment and acquittal of President Clinton.

title: Biden Faces the Front-Runner's Perils
summary: He starts off strong, but as Hillary Clinton can attest, that's not necessarily enough.. Even before Joe Biden announced he was running for president, pundits savaged him. A CNN editor at large dismissed the 76-year old as "a white man who has spent his entire professional life in elected office" running "to lead a party that is increasingly dominated by younger, more diverse voices." A University of Georgia professor wrote in the Guardian that Mr. Biden's manifold sins made him "the worst candidate for the Democrats" and "the best opponent for Trump." Labeling the former vice president's candidacy "a joke," a CNBC senior columnist blasted him as "ill-fitted to a Democratic Party" that is embracing an ambitious "progressive economic agenda" and "full-bore identity politics/minority leadership."

title: Jerry Nadler's 'Dictator'
summary: Democratic paeans to checks and balances conceal plans for a historic power grab.. Democrats' assaults on the Trump presidency roll in like the ocean's tides. But one has landed on the beach recently that deserves to go under the microscope. It is the notion that Donald Trump is a dictator.

title: The Pros and Cons of Facial Recognition
summary: Debate safety and civil liberties before it becomes ubiquitous.. San Francisco has become the first city to forbid local agencies from using facial-recognition software. The Stop Secret Surveillance Ordinance, enacted Wednesday, asserts that the technology's "propensity . . . to endanger civil rights and civil liberties substantially outweighs its purported benefits."

title: 'The Global Age' Review: Europe on the Upswing
summary: Post-1950, Europe, despite challenges, saw a substantial increase in living standards and a drop in political and ethno-nationalist violence.. In May 2017, at the conclusion of the G7 summit in Italy, German Chancellor Angela Merkel-perturbed by the behavior of President Trump, from his hostility to the European Union as a trading bloc to his questioning of the value of NATO-proclaimed that "we Europeans must really take our fate into our own hands." But a defining feature of postwar European history is that grandiose calls-to-arms are rarely pursued with the same urgency-or the same fatal consequences-as in the first half of the 20th century. The benign sluggishness can be seen in the foot-dragging over defense spending and in European leaders' endless calibration of both their national interests and their nominal fidelity to the ideal of deeper European integration. A continent still controlled by centrist technocrats moves slowly toward a vaguely defined future destination.

title: CIOs Turn Automation on Their Own Departments
summary: More tech tasks are being done by robots as businesses look to keep costs down. Corporate information-technology managers driving automation across a range of business divisions are finally focusing on their own departments-often the last to be upgraded with new workplace technology.

title: Buckling Up in the Back Seat May Soon Be Mandatory in New York
summary: AAA Northeast found in a 2016 report that 886 unbelted New Yorkers died in vehicle crashes between 1994 and 2015. Back seat passengers could soon be required to wear seat belts in New York under a bill that is advancing in the state legislature.

title: Trump Can't Afford to Go Soft on Turkey
summary: Erdogan's purchase of a Russian air-defense system is a serious threat to U.S. national security.. Turkish President Recep Tayyip Erdogan may be playing dumb, but he's not stupid.

summary: 'He is vulnerable to attacks from the left on issues such as climate change'. Andrew Buncombereporting for England's Independent, May 14:

title: Phillip Swagel Expected Named Next Congressional Budget Office Director
summary: Former Treasury economist during George W. Bush administration will succeed Keith Hall starting June 3. WASHINGTON-Congressional leaders have chosen Phillip Swagel, a top Treasury Department economist during the George W. Bush administration, as the next director of the Congressional Budget Office, the chairmen of the Senate and House Budget Committees said Wednesday.

title: U.S. Suspends Commercial Passenger, Cargo Flights to and From Venezuela
summary: Department of Homeland Security says conditions in strife-torn nation threaten the safety of passengers, crew and aircraft. WASHINGTON-The Trump administration suspended all commercial passenger and cargo flights between the U.S. and Venezuela, citing safety concerns stemming from political instability and economic turmoil in the South American nation.

title: Visited the Statue of Liberty? Not if You're a New Yorker
summary: Many Locals, Yearning to Breathe Free, Avoid Huddled Masses of Tourists. With the public unveiling of the Statue of Liberty's new museum Thursday, the 132-year-old national monument is poised to boost attendance even beyond the 4 million-plus annual visitors it receives.

title: Leaders of Three Pacific Islands Plan Joint Visit to U.S.
summary: Presidents of Palau, Micronesia and Marshall Islands to meet with Trump next week. The leaders of three strategic Pacific island countries will visit the U.S. next week to cultivate long-held alliances amid efforts by Washington to counter expanding Chinese influence in the region, the White House said.

title: Helicopter Crashes in New York City's Hudson River; No One Is Seriously Hurt
summary: Pilot was only person on board. A helicopter crashed into the Hudson River soon after taking off from a heliport on Manhattan's West Side, the New York Police Department said.

summary: The exhibition is filled with work expressing political and social grievances, but feels like it may be preaching to the converted.. New York

FRANKFURT-Germany's economy rebounded in the first quarter after narrowly avoiding recession late last year, easing the immediate pressure on policy makers in Europe as the outlook continues to darken for global trade.

summary: Resume Subscription. The dollar rose on Wednesday after the U.S. said it would delay imposing tariffs on auto imports.

summary: Sales decline at Restaurant Brands mirrors trouble at other 3G-supported companies. Burger King parent Restaurant Brands International Inc. is under pressure from investors to show it has a plan to boost sales at its restaurant chains.

summary: Tobacco company promoting Vuse e-cigarettes on Twitter, Instagram to users over 21 years old. One of the biggest U.S. tobacco companies has started marketing its e-cigarettes on Twitter and Instagram, seeking to regain market share lost to upstart Juul Labs Inc.

summary: Decision to own properties is an effort to control lease prices and capitalize on asset-price growth. It is hard to find a real-estate boom that hasn't ended badly for piggy-backers. What could possibly go wrong?

summary: The industrial metal swings higher after news that the Trump administration won't impose tariffs on autos. Copper prices rose Wednesday, boosted by hopes of easing trade tensions.

summary: State also says the e-cigarette maker is misrepresenting health risks of the products' nicotine. North Carolina officials are suing Juul Labs Inc., accusing the e-cigarette startup of targeting teenagers and misrepresenting the strength and health risks from the addictive nicotine in its products.

title: Lawmakers Question FAA's Credibility in Boeing 737 MAX Safety Approval
summary: Delegating safety-certification process to third parties is 'not working as Congress intended,' says House panel chairman. WASHINGTON-The Federal Aviation Administration has a "credibility problem" related to its safety certification of Boeing Co. 's 737 MAX aircraft, according to the chairman of a House panel.

title: The Met Stops Taking Gifts From Purdue Pharma's Sacklers
summary: New York museum is latest institution that won't accept donations from family that owns opioid maker. The Metropolitan Museum of Art in New York said it would stop accepting donations from members of the Sackler family associated with drugmaker Purdue Pharma LP, the latest institution to halt gifts amid scrutiny of the drug company's role in the opioid epidemic.

title: White House Wants Patients to Know Health-Care Prices Up Front
summary: Administration wants to require up-front disclosure of prices patients will pay for treatment-and rates insurers negotiate with providers. summary: After stocks breached key averages in the first four months of the year, some analysts are wary a reversal will spur punishing drops. summary: Move is credit-card company's latest effort in push to link cardholders with perks-offering partners. title: Georgetown University to Expel Two Students Tied to Admissions Scandal
summary: One of the students sued the university for denying him due process. Georgetown University said Wednesday it would expel two students implicated in the college-admissions scandal-hours after one of the students sued the school for allegedly depriving him of due process.

summary: The two leaders are to discuss efforts toward denuclearization of North Korea, White House says. WASHINGTON-President Trump will travel to South Korea, in conjunction with his trip to Japan for the Group of 20 summit, to pursue efforts to get North Korea to denuclearize.

title: CFPB Enforcement Head Resigns After Past Comments Criticized as Racist
summary: Eric Blankenstein, official tasked with policing discrimination, to step down following rebukes over earlier writings on hate crimes. title: Treasurys Strengthen on Signs of Economic Weakness
summary: Yields extend their decrease after U.S. data show industrial production and retail sales fell. U.S. government bonds rose Wednesday as the latest flurry of data pointed to some weakness in the world's two biggest economies.

title: WNBA Hires Deloitte CEO as Commissioner
summary: First woman to lead a Big Four accounting firm takes new role as women's basketball league faces labor talks. Cathy Engelbert, the first woman to lead one of the Big Four U.S. accounting firms, will be taking the reins of the U.S. women's professional basketball league ahead of labor talks that could financially reshape the league.

title: Sudan Takes First Tentative Steps Toward Democratic Rule
summary: The proposed 300-member legislative body would have two-thirds of its seats reserved for civilian representatives from a coalition of protesters. Leaders of Sudan's military and the protest movement that unseated dictator Omar al-Bashir agreed on a three-year blueprint for democratic rule, days after clashes between the two sides left at least four people dead.

title: New Jersey Legislators Take Pass on Pot
summary: Senate President Steve Sweeney said he wants voters to have the final word. New Jersey lawmakers abandoned efforts to pass legislation legalizing recreational marijuana and instead plan to put it before voters on the 2020 ballot.

title: Stocks Turn Higher on Trade Hopes
summary: Dow industrials rise more than 100 points after report Trump plans to delay tariffs on car imports. U.S. stocks climbed, advancing for a second consecutive session on hopes that thawing trade tensions will boost the outlook for the world economy.

title: In U.S.-Iran Standoff, Gulf States Steer Clear of Confrontation
summary: Muted responses to recent attacks reflect concern for another conflict in war-racked region. Saudi Arabia and its Persian Gulf allies haven't called for a confrontation with Iran over recent attacks in the region that the U.S. has said Tehran likely initiated, a tack that reflects their limited appetite for another conflict in the war-racked region.

title: Weinstein Co. to Liquidate in Bankruptcy
summary: Wind-down of Harvey Weinstein's former studio has turned to resolving potential claims against former board, company says. What remains of Harvey Weinstein's former film studio will be liquidated in bankruptcy court, the company said, as lawyers try to resolve civil litigation against its ex-officers and directors arising out of Mr. Weinstein's alleged sexual abuse.

title: A Historic Shortage of Americans
summary: Birth rates hit record lows; the need for new people has never been greater.. Americans are having babies at the lowest rate ever recorded as the population stagnates. Meanwhile, Washington keeps making more promises on behalf of future workers.

title: Digital Freight Brokers Turn Physical With Truck Equipment Pools
summary: Convoy, Uber and others are providing trailers to speed cargo movement, boost productivity. Digital freight marketplaces that connect shippers and truckers online are turning toward more physical operations by offering the equipment that cargo carriers need to move loads.

title: For Democrats, Union Dominance Is Destiny
summary: Public unions still flex their muscles in all 20 blue states won by Hillary Clinton in 2016.. Allysia Finley's "Blue State Politics Are Eroding Little Rhody's Big Reforms" is a cautionary tale for moderate voters in 2020 who might imagine that a Democratic presidential candidate won't be captive to progressive interests after winning the White House (Cross Country, May 4). Gov. Gina Raimondo was first elected in 2014 in deep-blue Rhode Island by touting a centrist reform agenda to dig the state out of a deep fiscal hole, but in the past two years she has been tugged to the left, primarily by the state's powerful government unions. Unions are pressing for legislation to protect their pay and benefits in perpetuity, and for changes in work rules and pension stipends that will put more stress on city and state budgets and taxpayers.

title: Flight Systems Have Become Too Complicated
summary: There are airline pilots that are not capable of recognizing and mitigating certain system failures.. Regarding Holman W. Jenkins, Jr.'s column "GM and Boeing Show How Safety Miscues Happen" (Business World, May 11): Most media reports portray Boeing as incompetent and inappropriately close with the Federal Aviation Administration. As Mr. Jenkins notes, any attempt by Boeing to defend its design is met with derision and contempt. This exaggerated portrayal increases the risk that the public will never recognize the real problem: Many current airline pilots are simply not up to the standard necessary to operate current systems. With that in mind, the airline industry-not just Boeing-needs to lower expectations related to pilot competency in designing systems and dealing with failures.

title: Microsoft Warns of Monster Bug, In a Week of Them
summary: The company has patched the flaw but says it is 'highly likely' it will wind up being exploited by malicious software. Microsoft Corp. took the unusual step of warning that a computer bug it has now patched could be used by a cyber weapon similar to the WannaCry worm, which spread across the globe two years ago.

summary: A concert and exhibition at the Country Music Hall of Fame and Museum honor the enduring legacy of Keith Whitley, who died 30 years ago..

title: Former Interpol Chief's Family Granted Asylum in France
summary: Grace Meng, the wife of the former president of the global police agency, has been in hiding since her husband's disappearance last year. title: Has Your Kid Withstood the History Censors?
summary: It's as if there is a concerted effort-and a successful one-to minimize our nation's past.. A recent op-ed by Fergus M. Bordewich had the headline "Even George Washington May Be Erased from Our Past" (April 27). A school in San Francisco has a mural of Washington's life, depicting many of its features-including that he owned slaves. Some activists are saying that the mural should be gone. They say it's traumatizing the students. For the previous 83 years the students weren't traumatized, or had never noticed it.

title: Is Luxury Weed the New Status Symbol?
summary: $950 sculptural water pipes at Barneys, cannabis packed in cut crystal decanters, and vape pens designed with executives in mind-is stoner culture as we knew it over forever?. When Adrian Sedlin got a call from his brother-in-law Randy Patten in 2015 to ask if Sedlin would buy him a building to grow weed in, Sedlin wasn't immediately on board. Before retiring three years earlier at age 42, Sedlin had a career taking over relatively early-stage companies to reposition their strategy, grow them and exit. Most recently, he'd turned around an online crime-mapping company called CrimeReports, which Motorola then bought. Patten had been a cannabis cultivator for 20 years.

title: Trump to Host Polish Leader at White House
summary: Two leaders to discuss defense cooperation and energy independence next month. WASHINGTON-President Trump will meet with Polish President Andrzej Duda at the White House next month for discussions about defense cooperation and energy independence, the White House said on Wednesday.

title: White House Counsel Calls for House Committee to Halt Investigation
summary: In letter, Pat Cipollone says Judiciary Committee should narrow the scope of its document requests. title: State Efforts to Quell Israel Boycott Movement Raise Free-Speech Objections

title: Wearing Your Phone: The Latest Absurd Fashion Trend?
summary: As smartphones increase in size and create unsightly pocket bulges, some men have taken to hanging their phones around their necks in tiny bags. BEEP, BEEP, BEEP. Throughout the 1990s, doctors, businessmen and the coolest of high-schoolers bopped along to the cutesy little chirps emitted by the pagers they had strapped to themselves at all times. Clipped to a belt or front pocket, pagers helped popularize wearable tech. You merely had to glance down to see who was buzzing you about the patient flatlining in the ER, or the latest food-court scandal.

title: The Calm of the Underwater Soundscape
summary: Whether you're in the ocean or a swimming pool, there's more to hear below the surface than you might expect. In the middle of my busiest days I crave escape, preferably to another world. It sounds like science fiction, but even in central London it is possible to step through a boundary to another realm and be back before the end of lunch break. The trick is to go swimming, because diving into the water means crossing a sharp acoustical line. On the other side is the alien world of underwater sound.

summary: As the HBO hit heads into its final episode Sunday, it has become an extreme example of how hard it is to deliver a satisfying finale to a beloved TV series. The looming finale of "Game of Thrones" on Sunday is causing an outbreak of anxiety among its obsessive fans.

summary: The five-bedroom, 6,000-square-foot luxury apartment in Lower Manhattan is the building's priciest unit. title: In Tribeca, A Place to Rest and Rumba
summary: Following a $400,000 renovation, the living room of competitive ballroom dancer Luda Conti doubles as a dance studio. Luda Conti, a spa owner and ballroom dancer, wanted the 1,000-square-foot living and dining room of her Tribeca apartment to have multipurpose function. The space needed to be easy for entertaining but the design needed to allow for Mrs. Conti, 60, to be able to practice her ballroom dancing.

title: How a Student's Job Affects College Aid
summary: Various factors govern how income from summer or part-time work is counted for financial-aid purposes. Will working during the summer or at a part-time job hurt a student's prospects for financial aid? It's a question that many students ask-and the answer can be confusing.

title: 'Game of Thrones' Spoiler Alert: A Spanish Doctor Will Tell You How It Ends
summary: Resume Subscription. Jose Señarís Romay was at work at a production studio in Madrid in late March when he received an urgent text message. An attorney representing HBO was outside with a contract for him to sign. It said, in essence, stop divulging plot twists of the final season of "Game of Thrones."

title: Canada Inflation Rate Accelerated in April
summary: Broad-based price increases unlikely to alter expectations that the Bank of Canada will keep rates on hold in coming months. OTTAWA-The annual inflation rate in Canada accelerated slightly in April on broad-based price increases for items such as mortgage payments, vehicles and fresh vegetables.

title: China's Top Tech Company Makes Peace With Beijing
summary: Gaming giant Tencent has patched up the differences with regulators that battered its stock last year. After a horrible year, one of China's tech superstars is back in the game.

title: U.S. Industrial Production Dropped in April
summary: Manufacturing output, the biggest component of industrial production, fell 0.5% in April from a month earlier. WASHINGTON-The U.S. manufacturing sector faltered again in April, fresh evidence that a slowing global economy and trade frictions are squeezing part of the U.S. economy.

title: Nordic, Baltic Regulators Agree to Share Info on Money-Laundering Threats
summary: Effort by eight countries comes as banks in the region face questions about anti-money-laundering compliance. Financial regulators in eight Nordic and Baltic countries have agreed to share more information about money-laundering threats in an effort to fight financial crimes.

title: Bazinga! Streaming Deal for 'The Big Bang Theory' Comes Into Play
summary: As the hit sitcom ends, AT&T's WarnerMedia must decide whether to try to keep the series for its new service or sell the rights to a rival like Netflix. There is still one unresolved plotline in "The Big Bang Theory," which ends its 12-year run Thursday on CBS: Who will get the hit sitcom's streaming rights?

title: Stocks to Watch: Macy's, McDonald's, Agilent, CVS
summary: Here are some of the shares expected to trade actively in Wednesday's session. Here are some of the companies with shares expected to trade actively in Wednesday's session. Stock movements noted by ticker reflect movements during regular trading hours; premarket trading is specified separately.

title: China's Economy Was Losing Steam Even Before Trump's New Tariffs
summary: Factory production, retail sales and investment in fixed assets all slowed in April. BEIJING-China says domestic spending by its own citizens will minimize the economic damage of its trade fight with the U.S. Yet demand from consumers and factories is looking shaky.

title: Time to Bet on Multiple Rate Cuts? Analysts Say It's Too Soon
summary: Fed-funds futures tilt closer to pricing in decreases, but economic data seem strong. Federal-funds futures suggest investors are more convinced than ever that the Federal Reserve will lower interest rates multiple times by the end of the year. Economic data suggest that is too drastic a bet.

title: White House Resistance to Budget Deal Worries Republicans
summary: Trump administration reluctant to approve two-year accord with defense and nondefense increases.

title: Stanley to Make More Craftsman Tools in U.S.
summary: Automated Texas factory to produce wrenches and sockets at costs similar to work now done in China. Stanley Black & Decker Inc. plans to move production of Craftsman wrenches from China back to the U.S., the latest manufacturer looking to use automation to increase domestic output as tariffs raise the cost of imports from overseas.

title: Will Slack Be Another Shocker?
summary: Slack's lack of profitability and choice of direct listing could hamper its near-term performance as a public company, despite waiting out the choppy market. Slack Technologies Chief Executive Stewart Butterfield likens his company's software to electricity: something life-changing that you can't live without. But while Slack's product may have caught fire, its public debut could still short-circuit.

title: Alabama Senate Passes Bill Effectively Banning Abortion
summary: Measure heads to governor; backers seek to provoke court challenge to Roe v. Wade. The Alabama Senate passed an antiabortion bill that would effectively ban the procedure and is aimed at reaching the U.S. Supreme Court to challenge a woman's right to terminate a pregnancy.

title: Amazon Gets a Leg Up From Weaker Rivals
summary: A U.K. fashion chain has become the latest European retailer to give the tech giant access to its stores. Amazon poses a strategic dilemma for Europe's retailers. They are reluctant to help such a powerful competitor but tempted by partnerships that can make struggling stores more profitable.

title: Foreign Investors are Checking Out of the Chinese Stock Market
summary: Record outflows from China's mainland-listed stocks confound expectations that their inclusion in indexes would underpin investor appetite. 2019 was meant to be the year many Western investors began buying Chinese stocks. It is turning out to be the first year many investors began selling them.

title: The Next Frontier in the Privacy Debate: Your Flight
summary: Airlines soon will have extensive new ways to track passengers, raising new concerns about the balance between convenience and data security. Red and green lights show passengers where to find overhead bin space. Sensors tip off flight attendants to which seats aren't upright and whose seat belt isn't fastened. Airlines track how much you sleep, how much you're out of your seat, what you watch and what you eat.

title: The Office of the Future Is No Office at All, Says Startup
summary: Everyone works remotely at software-development company GitLab, even its CEO. GitLab Inc. is extreme, even for Silicon Valley: It has no headquarters and everyone works remotely, even the CEO.

title: Artwork That Once Symbolized Venezuela's Rise Now a Shelter From Crime
summary: A guarded giant orb has become a hangout for struggling Caracas residents with few entertainment options. CARACAS, Venezuela-Artist Jesús Soto created the "Caracas Sphere"-a giant orange orb suspended in the air, seemingly defying gravity-to honor what he saw as a rising oil nation in the '90s.

title: 'We're Already Doing It': Japan Tests Unorthodox Economic Doctrine
summary: Modern monetary theory is at center of debate over tax increase, and advocates say Tokyo needn't worry about government deficits. TOKYO-In the U.S., modern monetary theory-which, in its crudest form, suggests government deficits don't matter-is still just an unorthodox doctrine debated mostly by economists and left-wing Democrats.

title: Thousands Cut Off by Closed Bridges After Missouri Floods
summary: Resume Subscription. Two months after record floods swept down the Missouri River, closed bridges are still making life hard for people like Mary Grace Thiltges.

title: The Real Signals in Another Month of Noisy Chinese Data
summary: There are plenty of reliable clues-if you know where to look. Well, investors were warned: April showers are indeed washing away all that sunny March optimism.

title: SoftBank Doubles Down on Indian Grocery Venture
summary: Grofers India receives just more than $200 million in a funding round led by the Vision Fund. NEW DELHI- SoftBank Group Corp. is doubling down on its bet on an Indian grocery-delivery startup, in the global investor's latest foray in the world's largest untapped tech market.

title: U.S. Births Fall to Lowest Level Since 1980s
summary: Resume Subscription. The number of babies born in the U.S. last year fell to a 32-year low, deepening a fertility slump that is reshaping America's future workforce.

title: Pepper...and Salt
summary: Resume Subscription. We are delighted that you'd like to resume your subscription.

title: Hospital Drug-Making Venture Picks Antibiotics as First Products
summary: Nonprofit Civica Rx plans to begin distributing vancomycin hydrochloride and daptomycin before the end of September. Two critical antibiotics will be the first products supplied by a group of hospitals that are trying to overcome high drug prices and short supplies by producing the medicines themselves.

title: As WeWork's Losses Mount, It Aims to Distance Itself From Uber
summary: Shared office-space giant has long been dogged by skepticism about its lofty valuation. As WeWork Cos. heads toward an initial public offering, its ebullient chief executive believes it shouldn't be lumped in the same category as massively money-losing companies like Uber Technologies Inc. and Lyft Inc.

title: The Dubious Management Fad Sweeping Corporate America
summary: NPS-or net promoter score-is a measure of customer satisfaction that has developed a cultlike following among CEOs. It also may be misleading.. Best Buy and American Express use it to dole out employee bonuses. Target and Intuit point to it to justify investments. Delta Air Lines and UnitedHealth can't stop talking about it.

title: Republican Dan Bishop Wins North Carolina Do-Over House Primary
summary: GOP avoids runoff as state senator draws more than 30% of vote. Republicans avoided a runoff Tuesday in the primary for North Carolina's do-over Ninth Congressional District race, a boon to the GOP's chances of holding the Charlotte-oriented seat this fall against a Democrat who has been campaigning for almost two years.

title: China: Trade Fight With U.S. Is 'No Big Deal' but Calls It a 'People's War'
summary: Beijing is balancing stoking patriotism at home while restraining its trade rhetoric for an international audience. BEIJING-China amped up its rhetoric in a tariff battle with the U.S., playing to nationalistic sentiment with strident state-media criticisms aimed at Washington, even as Beijing reiterated its preference for a negotiated resolution.

title: Monet Sells for $110.7 Million, Breaking Artist's Record
summary: Sotheby's sells 'Haystacks' from famed series to woman sitting in the back of the room; bidder also won a Caillebotte for $14 million. Claude Monet's eponymous 1890 painting of haystacks turned purple under a setting sun, sold Tuesday for $110.7 million-a record for the impressionist-to an unidentified woman who had to raise her paddle aloft to be spotted from the second-to-last row of Sotheby's in New York.

title: As MTA Scrutinizes Worker Overtime, Union Raises Specter of Transit Strike
summary: 'A strike is not a far-fetched notion anymore,' union president says. The head of the transit union representing New York City's subway and bus workers has raised the prospect of a labor strike as the Metropolitan Transportation Authority seeks to combat overtime abuse.

title: Payday Lenders Drum Up Customer Support to Ease Regulations
summary: CFPB is flooded with comments, many using the same templates. WASHINGTON-Payday lenders have been mobilizing their customers to push the federal government to ease Obama-era regulations of the industry, according to research by a consumer advocacy group that favors the rules.

title: The New Orleans Pelicans Win the Zion Williamson Lottery
summary: They had a 6% shot at the No. 1 pick in the NBA draft. And then they got lucky. It might have changed the entire league if they're able to keep Anthony Davis.. It could have been the New York Knicks. It might have been the Los Angeles Lakers. But it was the New Orleans Pelicans that won the NBA draft lottery on Tuesday night and the right to select basketball phenomenon Zion Williamson, the most hyped prospect since LeBron James, with the No. 1 pick in next month's draft.

title: Attacks to Raise Security, Insurance Costs for Persian Gulf Oil Shipments
summary: Oil prices climb 1.2% after drone attacks damage major Saudi pipeline. Recent attacks on Saudi Arabian oil tankers and pipelines are set to increase the cost of insuring and securing crude shipments in the Persian Gulf region, added expenses that will likely lead to higher oil prices, industry executives said.

title: Iran Blames U.S. for Tensions in Mideast
summary: Foreign minister said 'radical individuals' were attempting to pull Iran and the U.S. into military conflict; drone attack by Houthi rebels allied to Tehran shut Saudi pipeline. Iran vigorously denied a U.S. claim that it was behind attacks on four oil tankers in the Persian Gulf that set the Middle East on edge, as the Trump administration confronted mounting skepticism from allies abroad and Democrats at home.
